titleStmt.title: The declaration and propositions of the Lord Maior of London to the Kings most Excellent Maiesty and and [sic] both Houses of Parliament, concerning a treaty for Peace. Together with the House of Commons answer to the said declaration. Also a true information of 800. Danes landing in Lincolnshire, Decemb. 20. And how the trained bands of that county gave them battell neer the towne of Lee, ond [sic] obtained a happy victory over them. Together with the resolution of the Hous [sic] of Commons concerning the Danee. Also a second victory obtained by Sergeant Major Skipton and Col, Browne at Chichester Decmb. 22. against the kings forces that lye there,
titleStmt.author: City of London (England). Lord Mayor.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

notesStmt.note: Sir Isaac Penington first became lord mayor August 16, 1642. cf. DNB.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE DECLARATION AND Propo≈øitions of the Lord Maior of London to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maie≈øty and and both Hou≈øes of Parliament, concerning a Treaty for Peace. Together with the Hou≈øe of Commons An≈øwer to the ≈øaid Declaration. Al≈øo a true Information of 800. Danes landing in Lincoln≈øhire, Decemb. 20. And how the Trained-Bands of rhat County gave them Battell neer the Towne of Lee, ond obtained a happy victory over them. Together with the Re≈øolution of the hou≈ø of Commons concerning the Danee. Al≈øo a ≈øecond Victory obtaind by Sergeant Major Skipton and Col, Browne at Chiche≈øter Decemb. 22. again≈øt the Kings Forces that lye there,

div.head: THE LORD MAJOR OF LONDON His Propo≈øitions to the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øty at Oxford, Decemb. 22.
div.p:
THE Lord Major of London, together with divers Citi≈øens, having ≈øeriou≈øly weighed and con≈øidered the pre≈øent E≈øtate and condition of this Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Kingdom, occa≈øioned by tho≈øe wicked and Malignant Spirits, that are enemies to the Common-wealth, and Adver≈øaries to the
publike good, having agreed upon certain propo≈øitions to be pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty for a reconciliation of the≈øe differencies between his Maje≈øty and both Hou≈øes of Parliament, upon Tue≈øday la≈øt the ≈øaid Lord Maior accompanied with divers of the Aldermen and Citizens went up to the Hou≈øe of Commons and propounded the≈øe following propo≈øitions in the name of them≈øelves and the whole City, it being directed to the Lords and Commons, which propo≈øitions were to this effect:

1. They gave the Parliament hearty thanks for their unwearied paine and care to ≈øettle the pre≈øent di≈øtractions of this Kingdomc, and their ≈øeverall addre≈ø≈øes to His Maje≈øty for the ≈øame, de≈øiring His Maje≈øty to come and ioyn with his Parliament for the e≈øtabli≈øhing and ≈øetling of firme peace.

Then ≈øeeing His Maje≈øty hath often declared, that hee could not with ≈øafety returne to the Parliament, by rea≈øon of the tumults rai≈øed in the City, they have drawn up a petition to his Maie≈øty expre≈ø≈øing
their loyalty and obedience towards him, to be as great as any of their predece≈ø≈øors, and they were ready to give His Maie≈øty all further a≈ø≈øurance of the ≈øame if His Maie≈øty would be graciou≈øly plea≈øed to come to His Parliament, &c. Which petition they al≈øo pre≈øented to the Commons, de≈øiring them to con≈øider of a way how the ≈øame might be ≈øent unto his Maie≈øty.

Upon Wedne≈øday la≈øt Letrers came to the Hou≈øe of Commons from Lincoln≈øhire, intimating, That on Sunday la≈øt there was 500. Danes landed in that Countie; But the Trained Bands there immediately aro≈øe, and being in number about 400. they marched toward them, and gave them Baitell neer the Town of Lee, where they ≈ølew about 50. of them. The Hou≈øe of Commons have Ordered, that ≈øome good Commanders ≈øhall be ≈øpeedily ≈øent downe to oppo≈øe the ≈øaid Danes.

div.head: The Parliaments An≈øwer to the fore≈øaid Propo≈øitions.
div.p: THe≈øe Propo≈øitions being read, the Sheriffes and Aldermen were called into the Hou≈øe, who returned them great thankes for their Petitions, and then their Petitions being communicated to the Lords, they al≈øo gave them thankes, and promi≈øed to joyne with the Commons concerning the ≈øame.

div.head: The Parliaments Propo≈øitions to the Kings Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.
div.p:
IT being often debated in the Lords Hou≈øe, concerning the framing of certaine Propo≈øitions for an Accommodation of Peace to be pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty, their Lord≈øhips at la≈øt having drawne up
the ≈øame, de≈øired a Conference with the Commons, at which Conference the ≈øaid propo≈øitions were read, and the Commons de≈øired to con≈øider of the ≈øame; and the ≈øaid propo≈øitions were to this effect:

1. That His Maje≈øty would be plea≈øed to give his Royall con≈øent to ≈øuch Bills as have already been agreed upon by both Hou≈øes of Parliam. among≈øt which is the Bill for taking away all Innovations out of the Church, a Bill again≈øt ≈øcandalous Mini≈øters, a Bill again≈øt Pluralities a Bill for the A≈ø≈øembly of the Clergy, for ≈øetling of Church Government, the Bill again≈øt Bi≈øhops, Deanes, and Chapters, &c.
2 That His Maje≈øty would pa≈ø≈øe a Bill for the better e≈øtabli≈øhing of the Rights, and priviledges of Parliament, and the liberty of the Subject.
3 That Delinquents might be delivevered up, or left to receive ≈øuch puni≈øhment as is agreeable to the Lawes of the Land, among≈øt which are nominated the Lord Digby, Wilmot, and others.
4 That His Maje≈øty would pa≈ø≈øe a „Äà‚óä„Äâ for the clearing of the Lord Kimbolton a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the 5. Members that were accu≈øed of the Hou≈øe of Commons.
5 That all Mini≈øters of State, Judg ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and other Officers that have beene received ≈øince the difference between His Maje≈øty and the parliament, may bee re≈øtored.

Col. Browne having ≈øent his pri≈øoner which he took at Winche≈øter to Port≈ømouth he and Sir W. Waller marched with the≈øe Forces to Chiche≈øter, where they met with a great party of the Kings Army, & drawing their men into a great Field, they began to charg each other, wher they fought for the ≈øpace of ≈øeven houres very couragiou≈øly, and at the la≈øt. Ser. Maj. Skipton came with 11. Troops of Hor≈øe and fel on ≈øo couragiou≈øly, that the Kings Army was put to flight, taking pri≈øoners and killing about 200 men with the lo≈ø≈øe of 40, And after the Fight they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of Arundel; and took Sir Rich. Rochford, and Mr. Rochford pri≈øoners.
